prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In order to detect and resolve the structures in the dense protostellar envelopes as obtained from MC27 by ALMA cycle 0, we intend to set the same observational parameters as our cycle 0 setup. This allow us to make a direct comparison with MC27.
Spectral lines and continuum Since the protostellar envelopes are supposed to have density of > 10^5 cm^-3, optically thin dust continuum and middle-J molecular lines with high critical densities are beneficial as already demonstrated in our cycle 0 observations. The HCO+ (3-2) line is a good tracers of dense gas. We also observe the HCN (3-2) line, which is reported to be a good indicator of outflowing gas, in the same IF band. In the densest part, these lines can be optically thick, and thus we use the H13CO+ (3-2) line to estimate the density and mass of the structures. For the combination of this line, we also take the CS (5-4) and SiO (6-5) lines. The CS (5-4) line can trace warmer gas than the HCO+ (3-2) because of the higher upper state energy (35 K), while the SiO (6-5) line is thought to be a shock tracer. Since the dynamical interactions such as outflow shock and collisions of condensations are expected to form shock heated gas, these lines will pick up the interacting regions.
Sensitivity and velocity resolution For the 1st science goal, we intend to detect outflow wings whose intensity is about 1 K known from the single-dish and ALMA cycle 0 observations. In order to estimate the flow velocity, 0.3 km/s resolution is required. We then set the line sensitivity of 0.1 K to achieve 10-sigma detections. For the 2nd science goal setting, the observing time is determined by the sensitivity of the H13CO+ line, which is the most important but the expected intensity is relatively weak. The peak antenna temperature is as high as 7 K for the dense condensation in MC27, and a few K for fainter structures. In order to achieve 10-sigma detections, we set the sensitivity of the H13CO+ line as 0.1 K and the linewidth of 0.3 km/s. With the on-source exposure time given by the line sensitivity, the continuum sensitivity per 1 baseband with 2 GHz bandwidth will be 0.11 mJy. The total 0.06 mJy sensitivity is enough to detect dust condensation seen in MC27 (1.8 mJy at the peak).
Mosaic size, angular resolution and the largest angular scale From the past single-dish observations, the protostellar envelopes are as extended as ~ 4000 AU. Also because the interaction with molecular outflow, shocked regions are expected to arise a few 1000 AU away from the central object. We there plan to make mosaic observations toward each target with the rectangular size of 25" (7 pointings each). From the image obtained from MC27 in cycle 0, we see dust condensations and gas stream of as small as ~ 1.5". The diameter of the detected dense condensation from MC27 is estimated to be 1.7", ~ 250 AU at the distance of 150 pc. We are not interested in extended component of the envelope, and the expected largest size of the structure is ~ 1400 AU, 9.3". Hence no ACA is required to have combined images.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The mass accretion onto young protostellar cores is a very important process for building stars. The physical process of the mass accretion is, however, not well studies observationally since protostars are deeply embedded in dense cloud cores. The ALMA cycle 0 data obtained from one of the youngest protostar, MC27, enclosed complex structures in the protostellar envelope, including a very dense (~ 10^7 cm^-3) and compact (~ 200 AU) gas condensation and elongated (~ 1000 AU) arc-like feature, that were not detected nor resolved by previous observations with PdBI and SMA. As demonstrated by a numerical simulation, such structures are likely to be dynamically interacting causing time variable episodic mass accretion, which is suggested to explain the long standing issue of "luminosity problem" of YSOs. We propose to search young protostars with different properties (in luminosity and molecular outflow activity) for the fragments of the envelopes. Although outflow-driving very faint objects are claimed to be candidates of the first hydrostatic cores, they could conceivably be protostars in the quiescent phase. Understanding the mass accretion will tell us true nature of protostars.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, Osaka Prefecture University
Astrophysical Sciences Department and Observatory, Princeton University
Graduate School of Science, Nagoya University
Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences, Kyushu University
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Graduate School of Science, Nagoya University
Graduate School of Science, Osaka Prefecture University
